text.headline: Press Pass Access with Tom Brokaw
Offutt Air Force Base, Nebraska
text.text: 18 October 1963

text.headline: KMTV: City of Omaha Department of Public Safety, Fire, and Police
Presidential Trip to Strategic Air Command (SAC) Headquarters
text.text:
29 September 1964

President Johnson reassured NATO membership and allies that America is ready to defend Europe if there ever were to be a threat against the continent. The trip to the SAC HQ not only reaffirmed Johnson’s commitment to NATO, but also to combat nuclear weapons and warfare.

text.headline: Congressional Access to the Georgia Senate
text.text:
05 January 1966

Brokaw's access to the Georgia General Assembly Senate chambers and floor

text.headline: Congressional Access to the Georgia House of Repesentatives
text.text:
10 January 1966

Brokaw's access to the chambers and floor of the Georgia General Assembly House of Representatives

text.headline: 1972 Republican National Convention
text.text:
21 August 1972

President Richard Nixon and Vice President Spiro Agnew would earn the Republican nomination from re-election. Nixon’s nomination would mark his fifth from the RNC. His appearance on the national ticket ties FDR for most; the two would be on the voting ticket in both vice presidential and presidential capacities. Agnew would end up resigning in 1973 from scandal and replacing him would be Gerald Ford. Following his role as the 40th vice president of the United States, Ford would become president of the United States following Nixon’s resignation as a result of Watergate. Ford is the only person to hold both offices without ever being elected by the Electoral College.

text.headline: Nixon's Presidential Trip to Xenia, Ohio
text.text:
09 April 1974

An F-5 tornado killed 33 people and injured more than 1,300 others April 3, 1974, in the town of Xenia, Ohio. The tornado was one of 148 tornados that swept the nation, in what would become known as a super outbreak. The Xenia tornado caused over $100 million in damage.

Nixon would visit Xenia and deliver remarks at a site of the devastation: a school. Xenia was hit the hardest, and this moment is still considered one of the most devastating natural disasters in American history.

Xenia would be the site of a second damaging tornado. This time, 26 years later, an F-4 tornado ripped through the town in a near identical path as the previous one in 1974.

text.headline: 1974 Moscow Summit
text.text:
28 June 1974

President Nixon met with General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev of the Communist party of the Soviet Union. The defining feature of the summit was the signing of the Threshold Test Ban Treaty. This agreement would prohibit nuclear tests having a yield exceeding a 150 kilotons limit and remove the possibility of testing new or existing nuclear weapons going beyond the defined limit.

Despite the agreement, there were several technical concerns that would cause problems for implementation. Brokaw would note in a post-it on this press pass that this event was “President Nixon trying to make an arms deal with Russia to save his presidency. He failed.”

This would be Nixon’s last international trip before resigning in August of that year.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 8/19/74
text.text:
19 August 1974

In one of his first public addresses as president, Ford would speak to the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Chicago. In his speech, Ford would support clemency for evaders of the Vietnam War draft.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 11/19/74
text.text:
19 November 1974

President Ford became the first sitting President to visit Japan. His trip included both Tokyo and Kyoto to meet with Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 11/22/74
text.text:
22 November 1974

Following his trip to Japan, Ford traveled to Seoul, South Korea, to meet with their head of state: President Park Chung-hee.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 11/23/74
text.text:
23 November 1974

Ford met with General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev during a trip to Vladivostok, Soviet Union. The meeting emphasized limiting nuclear weapons and missiles. Limitations included strategic nuclear delivery vehicles (SNDVs), intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), and submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBMs) that were fitted with multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles (MIRVs). The agreement emphasized that each nation would have equal aggregate numbers of these weapons.

For more information about this trip and the agreement, click here.

text.headline: National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame Awards Dinner
text.text:
10 December 1974

The 1974 Hall of Fame Awards were different from any that came before or after. At this time, players were on strike and picketed free-agency rules. Players were joined by other players’ unions to combat restrictions the NFL placed on its players at the time. The uniqueness of the moment was highlighted by the annual hall of fame game, which included several rookies and, as Sports Illustrated noted, “nobodies.” To read more of the SI story about this moment, click here.

text.headline: Ford Family Christmas Vacation
text.text:
22 December 1974

The Fords frequented Vail, Colorado, during the holiday break. They visited so often that an athletic complex and a garden are now named after the President and the First Lady respectively. Ford’s library has several headlines and news coverage archived for public viewing. Those archives can be seen here.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/28/75
text.text:
28 May 1975

The 1975 NATO Summit was the third since signing the North Atlantic Treaty in April of 1949. The NATO heads of state and governments traveled to Brussels, Belgium to participate in both formal and informal meetings from May 28-31.

text.headline: 1975 NATO Summit
text.text:
30 May 1975

The 1975 NATO Summit was the third since signing the North Atlantic Treaty in April of 1949. The NATO heads of state and governments traveled to Brussels, Belgium to participate in both formal and informal meetings from May 28-31.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/31/75
text.text:
31 May 1975

Following his participation in the NATO Summit, President Ford traveled to Madrid, Spain, to meet with Generalissimo Francisco Franco. During this trip, Ford received the keys to Madrid from its mayor, Miguel Angel García-Lomas Mata.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 6/1/75
text.text:
01 June 1975

President Ford’s European tour ended in Salzburg, Austria, home to the iconic Sound of Music von Trapp home. His trip included meeting with the Austrian Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and the President of Egypt, Anwar Sadat.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 7/3/75
text.text:
03 July 1975

Just a day before the annual White House Fourth of July celebration, President Ford headed to Cincinnati, Ohio, to dedicate the National Environmental Research Center. His trip also included a conference on domestic and economic affairs, as well as him participating in the Independence Festival Supper fundraising dinner in Cleveland that night.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 7/26/75 - 1
text.text:
26 July 1975

Ford's next European trip began in Bonn, Germany, before taking him to Poland, Finland, Romania, and Yugoslavia.

text.headline: Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe
text.text:
26 July 1975

While on a trip to countries in Eastern Europe, President Ford ventured to Helsinki, Finland, to participate in the opening session of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The meeting included heads of state from Finland, Great Britain, Turkey, West Germany, France, Italy, and Spain. The conference also included a meeting between Ford and USSR General Secretary Brezhnev. According to a post-it note Brokaw left on this press pass, the event and the signing of an international human rights agreement on August 1, was “Unprecedented.”

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 7/26/75 - 2
text.text:
26 July 1975

Ford’s fifth presidential trip to Europe included several stops in Eastern Europe, particularly Germany and Poland. During visits to both countries, Ford met with their heads of state. The trip concluded with visits to Romania and Yugoslavia following Ford’s Helsinki visit.

text.headline: Abardareva, Belgrade, Yugoslavia
text.text: 29 July 1975

text.headline: G6 Summit
text.text:
14 November 1975

The United States took part in the first G6 Summit, known as the Economic Summit meeting of the Heads of State. The summit was healed in Rambouillet, France, and included the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, and the United Kingdom. This group are all included in the current make-up of the G7: Canada is the additional member. Russia would later be included, totally the number to the G8, but would be later removed in 2014 amid human rights violations and concerns.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 11/29/75 - 1
text.text:
29 November 1975

Ford’s Presidential Trip to the Pacific

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 11/29/75 - 2
text.text:
29 November 1975

In his seventh international trip as president, Ford visited China, Indonesia, and the Philippines. Ford’s first stop in Beijing, China, focused on normalizing relations with the nation. He met with Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong and Vice Premier Deng Xiaoping.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 12/5/75
text.text:
05 December 1975

The second stop in Ford’s Pacific Trip was in Jakarta, Indonesia. There Ford met with the nation’s head of state: President Suharto.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 12/6/75
text.text:
06 December 1975

The last stop in Manila included a meeting Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos. While in Manila, President Ford signed the All Handicapped Children Act of 1975, which provided special education programming throughout the United States.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 1/5/76
text.text:
05 January 1976

On a trip to St. Louis, Missouri, President Ford spoke to the American Farm Bureau Federation Convention. To read Ford’s speech defending the need for agriculture and farming, click here.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 2/8/76
text.text:
08 February 1976

Ford spoke in front of 3,500 students are the University of New Hampshire’s convocation. Following his speech, which very little is known about or documented, the President and First Lady participated in a Q&A with students.

text.headline: 1976 Florida Primary
text.text:
09 March 1976

Brokaw reported from Orlando on the day of the Florida primary. Future-President Carter won on the Democratic side with 34% of the vote; Ford would beat future-President Reagan with 53% of the vote for the Republican side of the ticket.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 3/11/76
text.text:
11 March 1976

In a trip to Rockford, Illinois, President Ford spoke to the Farm Bureau Forum, continuing to emphasize the importance of farming and agriculture on the American economy. He would also speak at the Greater Rockford Tool and Die and Precision Machining Association that day. His trip would conclude with a campaign rally in an attempt to continue his success in the Presidential Primaries.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 4/9/76
text.text:
09 April 1976

In another domestic Presidential trip, Ford traveled to several Texas cities. He began his day in San Antonio, where he toured the Alamo and delivered an address to a Texas Republican reception. He would then go to Dallas to get a special briefing at the School of Business Administration of Southern Methodist University. According to his Presidential Daily Diary, he ended the day with a campaign fundraising event, a baseball game, and a dinner hosted by the Irving Texas Bar Association.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 4/22/76
text.text:
22 April 1976

The President would receive another key to a city, this time it would be for Indianapolis, Indiana, from its mayor, Mayor Hudnut. Ford would also be presented with a stone Seal of the United States made by elementary school students from Broadview Elementary in Bloomington, Indiana. His trip would conclude with an address at Butler University to approximately 8,000-10,000 guests. According to his Presidential Daily Diary, the guests included members of the faculty and student body, service clubs and organizations, and friends of the university. The general public was also able to attend.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 4/27/76
text.text:
27 April 1976

While in Louisiana, President Ford participated in the 28th annual Holiday in Dixie, a festival that also served as a rally for him. The event was held in the Northwest corner of Louisiana, the Northeast corner of Texas, and the Southwest corner of Arkansas. Collectively, the area is known as Ark-La-Tex. The Ambassador’s Club, Incorporated, held the event in Bossier City. Ford would also participate in a “Salute to the Military” dance, according to his Presidential Daily Diary.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/12/76
text.text:
12 May 1976

President Ford headed to the land of Ford vehicles to participate in a number of taped interviews and a reception with the Economic Club of Detroit. This trip included another key to a city; this time, Mayor Staples of Birmingham, Michigan, presented the President with the key to his city. To conclude his trip, President Ford toured the Ford Van Dyke Chassis Plant and participated in a campaign rally, according to his Presidential Daily Diary.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/22/76
text.text:
22 May 1976

Ford spent nearly a week’s worth of time travelling to California, Las Vegas, and Oregon. One of these stops included receiving an honorary doctorate from Warner Pacific College in Oregon. After several large speaking events, interviews, and fundraising rallies, Ford concluded his trip with a stop in Ohio. He would return to the White House following a campaign rally in Ohio.

text.headline: America's Bicentennial
text.text:
04 July 1976

An East Coast historical tour that began at Valley Forge and continued through Philadelphia, New York, and Washington, D.C., to celebrate the 200th birthday of the United States of America.

text.headline: 1976 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
12 July 1976

The Democrats and their delegates arrived in New York City in July 1976 to call the iconic Madison Square Garden its home for the selection of their 1976 Presidential election; it was the first DNC since 1924 to be held in NYC. The delegates would select former Georgia governor Jimmy Carter to lead the ticket. With Walter Mondale of Minnesota at his side, Carter would accept the nomination and begin his formal presidential campaign. At the convention, Barbara Jordan became the first African-American woman to deliver the keynote address. Lindy Boggs also was the first woman to preside over a national political convention. The Carter-Mondale ticket would win the 1976 election.

text.headline: 1977 G7 Summit
text.text:
05 May 1977

The third G7 Summit was hosted by the British Prime Minister in London. The Group of Seven, which consists of the richest industrialized countries, aren’t mean to be linked broader international institutions. Instead, the goal was for the group to discuss economic and political issues that the group could collaboratively address. The most recent addition to the G7 was Canada. It wasn’t until 1981 that the European Commission President was invited.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/5/77
text.text:
05 May 1977

President Carter’s trip to the G7 included him visiting a number of landmarks in London. He would then travel the NATO Ministerial Meeting in Switzerland. Here he met with European heads of state.

text.headline: National Women's Conference 1977
text.text:
18 November 1977

The four-day event focusing on women’s issues commenced in November 1977. Around 2,000 delegates arrived in Houston for the event; additionally, between 15,000 and 20,000 observers participated in the conference.

The conference is considered a national turning point, showcasing a moment of political history for second-wave feminism in the United States. Issues like abortion rights and sexual orientation were significant points of discussion at the conference.

text.headline: John Denver Celebrity Pro-Am Ski Tournament
text.text:
02 March 1978

The annual celebrity ski tournament hosted by John Denver included Josef Odermatt, Hank Kashiwa, Tyler Palmer, Jim Hunger, Werner Mattle, Werner Bleiner, Ed Reich, Andre Arnold, Jill St. John, David Soul, Clint Eastwood, Carol Wayne, and Caitlyn Jenner as guests.

text.headline: Vienna Summit
text.text:
06 June 1979

President Carter and Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev met to sign the SALT-II agreement. This agreement focused on limitations and guidelines for nuclear weapons; however, it proved to be one of the most controversial treaties of the Cold War. Talks emerged from the United States fearing the Soviet’s exponential growth in the arms race and the Soviet’s concern about the US/communist China relationship.

text.headline: US Open
text.text:
28 August 1979

The annual tennis tournament saw John McEnroe and Tracy Austin win men’s and women’s singles titles respectively. The event was highlighted by its youthful winner. At the time, McEnroe was only 20-years-old. According to the Washington Post, McEnroe’s win over Ilie Nastase saw the “Superbrat” emerge victorious after a near-riot amid the match. ESPN would eventually describe the moment as one of the top “ten quirky and controversial moments at the US Open.”

To read the Post’s article, click here.

To read ESPN’s complete list, click here.

text.headline: 1980 Iowa Caucuses
text.text:
21 January 1980

Jimmy Carter looked to become a two-term president with a win over Edward Kennedy, Jerry Brown, and other Democrat candidates in the first stop of the election year: Iowa. Carter would win the state’s caucus. Forty years later, Iowa’s caucus would be the site of much turmoil and technological failure leading to many assuming it would be the last time a caucus existed on the road to the Presidential nominations. Carter would ultimately lose the election and become a one-term president. Republican nominee Ronald Reagan would win the election 489 electoral votes to Carter’s 49. To read more about the “Reagan Revolution”, click here.

text.headline: 1980 Wimbledon
text.text:
23 June 1980

The 1980 Wimbledon not only saw McEnroe play in the finals in his second consecutive year, but tennis icon Billie Jean King also picked up her racket and played till the finals of Wimbledon in her return to the sport. Both McEnroe and King would lose their respective matches, but, regardless, history was made.

text.headline: 1980 Republican National Convention
text.text:
14 July 1980

The soon-to-be President-elect, Ronald Reagan, took the stage in the 1980 Republican National Convention to accept his party’s nomination. The former actor and California governor from Illinois selected George H.W. Bush of Texas to be his vice president. What would later become a slogan for Trump and his followers, Reagan originally coined the theme “Let’s Make America Great Again” in the Joe Lewis Arena. The convention opened with former President Gerald Ford, who spoke to the crowd on his 67th birthday.

The 1980 RNC remains the only national political convention to be held in Detroit.

text.headline: 1980 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
11 August 1980

As the first and only city to host consecutive political conventions, New York City again welcomed the Democratic National Convention back to Madison Square Garden. While the party nominated incumbent president Carter to lead the ticket for the 1980 election, Senator Ted Kennedy sought to have candidates released from their commitments. Kennedy throughout the primaries was Carter’s political rival for the nomination. It would be the last time in the 20th Century that this would occur.

Carter’s eventual landslide loss in the 1980 election would make him the 8th one-term president in American history. Reagan’s vice president, George H.W. Bush, would eventually become the 9th.

text.headline: 1981 Inaugural Ceremonies
text.text:
20 January 1981

Ronald Reagan’s inauguration marked a historic moment: he became the oldest president in American history. At nearly 70 years old, Reagan began his first of two terms on a warm January day. Shortly after delivering his remarks, American hostages were released from a 444-day captivity. The country was lit in celebration and bathed in yellow ribbons, what would become the symbol for solidarity of American hostages.

Reagan would remain the oldest American President until the election of Donald Trump 36 years later.

To read Reagan’s address, click here.

text.headline: Space Shuttle Mission - 4/12/81
text.text:
12 April 1981

NASA launched STS-1 (Space Transportation System-1) on the 20th anniversary of the first human spaceflight—performed by USSR pilot Yuri Gagarin. STS-1, also known as Columbia, was the first orbiter. During it’s 54.5-hour flight, Columbia orbited the Earth 36 times.

Commander John W. Young and pilot Robert L. Crippen crewed Columbia. Launching on the 20th anniversary, according to NASA, was purely a coincidence. The flight was supposed to take off two days before, but technical problems caused a delay.

text.headline: 1981 Wimbledon
text.text:
22 June 1981

The 1981 Wimbledon Championship saw a rematch of the 1980 finals between John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg. This time, unlike the 1980 finals, McEnroe came out on top. According to the New York Times, McEnroe’s temper was in full view on and off the court. He had several angry post-match news conferences with British reporters, which was elevated following his win. The contentious relationship with the press was clear after McEnroe stormed out of the post-championship presser when he was asked about his recent split with his girlfriend, tennis player Stacy Margolin. McEnroe’s temper in his opening-day loss, according to the article, also resulted in him being fined and warned of potential suspension.

To read the original NYT story, click here.

text.headline: The Royal Wedding
text.text:
29 July 1981

Considered to be one of the most well-known fairy-tale weddings, the marriage of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer captured the world’s attention. The traditional Church of England service took place at St. Paul’s Cathedral. Over 750 million people were estimated to be watching the ceremony on live television, with several outlets billing it as the “wedding of the century.” Since it was declared a national holiday, throughout the Commonwealth different events were held to mark the moment of celebration.

Eleven years later the couple separated; in 1996 they divorced. The tabloid-laden relationship ended ultimately ended with Diana’s death in 1997.

text.headline: The Showdown: Sugar Ray Leonard v. Thomas Hearns
text.text:
16 September 1981

The fight, which brought together two of boxing’s most notable names, was watched by an estimated 300 million people and a live crowd of 23,618. Before the match, Thomas Hearns had an undefeated record of 32-0 and Sugar Ray Leonard only suffered one career loss with a record of 30-1. Leonard would hand Hearns his first loss after 14 rounds. He would be awarded the unified world welterweight championship. The fight is considered one of the greatest in boxing history.

To read more about the fight, click here.

text.headline: Space Shuttle Mission - 11/12/81
text.text:
12 November 1981

The second flight of Columbia lasted two days. NASA’s goal was a second safe launch of an STS; this proved that. The original flight was supposed to be five days but was cut short due to a failed fuel cell.

To read about the flight, click here.

text.headline: Santa Rita Massacre
text.text:
17 March 1982

Amid the El Salvador Civil War, four Dutch journalists were murdered in what became known as the Santa Rita Massacre in 1982. The civil war lasted twelve years with the death of six Jesuits in 1989 being among the most historically known losses. The civil war included several murders and assaults of American missionaries. According to the Center for Justice and Accountability, human rights violations were incredibly common during this time, as well as the recruitment of children as soldiers. The most well-known incident of the El Salvador Civil War is the death of Archbishop Oscar Romero in 1980. Romero was murdered while holding mass. The Vatican considered him a “martyr for the faith,” which led to his canonization in 2018. To read the Vatican’s reflection on Romero’s life, click here.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 6/7/82
text.text:
07 June 1982

Following the United Nations vote on the Falkland Crisis, an undeclared war between the United Kingdom and Argentina, President Reagan made his first trip to Great Britain—and the first in five years by a sitting president. According to the New York Times, what made it an even more important trip is that it was the first trip since President Woodrow Wilson in 1919 to be an invited trip by the Queen as a guest. Reagan was not popular or overly well-received in Great Britain.

To read the original NYT article, click here.

text.headline: Space Shuttle Mission - 6/27/82
text.text:
27 June 1982

Two men returned to space for the fourth flight of the Space Shuttle Columbia (STS-4). This flight extended further in time than the previous three when it launched June 27 and landed on the Fourth of July. This flight, according to NASA, was the last test flight for the shuttle. This meant that Columbia was declared fully operational.

text.headline: Peacekeeping in Beirut
text.text:
16 August 1982

Philip C. Habib, US Special Envoy, presented a proposal for deploying a multinational peacekeeping force to Israel for Lebanon. Israel’s acceptance of the proposal was a major step in withdrawing Palestinian guerrillas from West Beirut, and it also was seen as removing a significant obstacle remaining in negotiations.

text.headline: Midterm Elections
text.text:
02 November 1982

Following Reagan’s 1980 presidential landslide the Democrats looked to change the Congressional chambers political leaning. The 1982 midterms saw the Republicans maintain power when the Democrats gained only one seat in the Senate. In the House of Representatives, Democrats gained 27 seats but not enough to achieve the majority. Not only did the 1980 US Census reapportionment led to the Democrats gaining Congressional seats, but they also gained seven state governorships. The Washington Post claimed this resulted from a 1982 economic recession and blame being placed on Reagan’s economic policies. They also noted this was the first time since 1928 the Republicans defended a majority.

text.headline: West Germany Elections
text.text: 06 March 1983

text.headline: Pilgrimage of Hope
text.text:
16 June 1983

Pope John Paull II did what many thought was the impossible. He visited Warsaw, Poland, following the imposition of martial law in the nation. The Vatican would claim that this trip was politically, socially, and religiously significant as the Polish communist authorities feared JPII’s visit. His visit was welcomed by millions in the Polish Solidarity movement, bringing them to see the Pope upon his arrival.

text.headline: 1984 Iowa Caucuses
text.text:
20 February 1984

The 1984 Democratic Primary included former Vice President Walter Mondale’s return to the campaign trail. In the Iowa Caucus, the first stop on the way to the November Presidential election. Modale would go on to win the caucus with 48.9% of the vote. To read about Mondale’s Iowa caucus victory and its importance, click here.

text.headline: 1984 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
16 July 1984

Walter Mondale was nominated to lead the Democratic side of the Presidential ticket. But the former VP made a much more historic move at the 1984 Democratic National Convention that took place at the Moscone Center in San Francisco. Mondale nominated Represented Geraldine Ferraro of New York to be his running mate. Ferraro’s nomination made her the first woman to be nominated by a major part for the presidency or vice presidency. Only three women would follow Ferraro on a major party ticket. She and Mondale would later lose the election; Reagan would win a second term.

Hillary Clinton remains as the only woman to lead a major party’s ticket when she ran (and lost) for President against Donald Trump in 2016. Sarah Palin, running mate to the late John McCain, was unsuccessful in her VP bid in 2008. Kamala Harris, President Joe Biden’s vice-presidential pick, was the first woman to win and hold one of the two highest posts in the United States; the two would beat Trump in the 2020 election. To read more about the history of women and the presidential ticket, including about the first woman to run for president (not from a major party), click here.

text.headline: 1984 Republican National Convention
text.text:
20 August 1984

The Republicans headed to Vice President George H.W. Bush’s home state for their 1984 national convention. The RNC being held in Dallas was the first of 33 conventions that was held in a southern state outside of Florida. The Republican’s nominated the Reagan/Bush ticket for a second run. The two would go on to win re-election in the 1984 general election.

text.headline: Geneva Summit - 1
text.text:
18 November 1985

A year after a successful election win, Reagan’s second term as president came face-to-face with Soviet General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev—the first meeting between the two. In what would be known as the Geneva Summit, the two discussed the Cold War-era arms race and reducing nuclear weapons. This meeting was the first in more than six years between the two nations.

Tom Brokaw anchored NBC Nightly News from Geneva November 18-20.

text.headline: Geneva Summit - 2
text.text:
19 November 1985

A year after a successful election win, Reagan’s second term as president came face-to-face with Soviet General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev—the first meeting between the two. In what would be known as the Geneva Summit, the two discussed the Cold War-era arms race and reducing nuclear weapons. This meeting was the first in more than six years between the two nations.

Tom Brokaw anchored NBC Nightly News from Geneva November 18-20.

text.headline: The People Power Revolution
text.text:
22 February 1986

Following the supposed re-election of President Ferdinand Marcos, hundreds of thousands of Filipinos took to the streets to protest Marcos’ claim he won over Carozon Aquino. According to the BBC, the protests overtook Marcos and forced his family and him to abdicate power and leave the Philippines. Despite overthrowing the dictator and the world watching as a revolution inspired anti-authoritarian activism, the social and economic inequalities only increased following Marco’s 20-year rule.

To read the BBC story, click here.

text.headline: Liberty Weekend
text.text:
03 July 1986

The Statue of Liberty turned 100, which served as the star of a grand Independence Day celebration by Reagan and his team.

text.headline: Reykjavík Summit
text.text:
11 October 1986

Reagan and Gorbachev met again, this time in Iceland. While it seemed like there was progress attempting to limit each other’s nuclear weapons capabilities, talks about sweeping change collapsed last minute. Historians see this summit as a turning point in the Cold War.

To read more, click here.

text.headline: The World Series
text.text:
18 October 1986

The Mets and Red Sox went all the way to game 7, with the Mets finally taking how the World Series title and the series 4-3.

text.headline: Sunkist Fiesta Bowl
text.text:
02 January 1987

The bowl game is known as the “Battle for #1” where the No. 1 ranked Miami Hurricanes faced the No. 2 Penn State Nittany Lions. The 16th Fiesta Bowl aired from the Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona. The Friday night game was the first part of NBC’s tripleheader of Bowl Games leading into the Rose Bowl. NBC drew a 25.1 rating for the game, which was seen in 21.9 million homes.

Penn State would beat Miami 14-10.

text.headline: Pope John Paull II Visit to America
text.text:
11 September 1987

The Pope began a 10-day American tour in Miami. According to the Vatican, he received an enthusiastic welcome from the crowd, which included President and Mrs. Reagan.

text.headline: The Changing China Telecast
text.text:
26 September 1987

Tom Brokaw aired live from Beijing, China, in what NBC defined as a “comprehensive portrait of a ‘Changing China.’” NBC sent over 100 people to China for this project.

text.headline: Washington Summit
text.text:
08 December 1987

Following their last summit in Iceland, Reagan met with Gorbachev in Washington. This time the discussion included several regional conflicts wrapped up in the Cold War, including issues in Afghanistan, Southern Africa, and Central America. Their discussion also surrounded around arms control issues and chemical weapons. This meant addressing the status of the START negotiations and human rights. The Washington Summit concluded with the signing of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty.

According to the Washington Post, the summit was a “success.”

To read the original article, click here.

text.headline: 1988 Moscow Summit
text.text:
29 May 1988

In what may be the most monumental of the Reagan/Gorbachev summits, this one ended with ceremonious success. While on a walk through the Red Square in Moscow, Reagan declared the Cold War had ended. This would be seen as Reagan’s last success in his presidency, which would conclude only a few months later.

text.headline: 1988 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
18 July 1988

Atlanta, Georgia, became the home of the ‘88 DNC where Massachusetts’ Governor Michael Dukakis was selected as the nominee for the party. He would choose Lloyd Bentsen, the senator from Texas, to be his running mate. The two would be unsuccessful in winning the White House, and thus the 80s would barely see a Democrat in presidential leadership with the exception of the 20 days Carter held the post before Reagan’s Inauguration.

text.headline: 1988 Republican National Convention
text.text:
15 August 1988

With Reagan’s two terms up, the Republicans looked to continue their conservative legacy into the new decade. While in New Orleans at the Superdome, the Republicans would select Reagan’s vice president, George H.W. Bush, as their nomination for the general election in November.

text.headline: 1988 Olympics
text.text:
17 September 1988

Officially known as the Games of the XXIV Olympiad, the 1988 Olympics were hosted in Seoul, South Korea. This would be the second summer games held in an Asian country, according to the International Olympic Committee. In total, 159 nations were represented and 237 held. The host country fared well, ranking fourth overall with 12 golds and 33 total medals.
What is notable about the Seoul 88 games is that they were the last of the Cold War, Soviet Union, and East Germany. All ceased to exist come the 1992 games. The USSR won 55 golds and 132 total medals, an astonishing feat no nation has come close to repeating since, according to the IOC. This also was the first Olympic games in a decade that was not marred by boycotts. The 1980 games in Moscow and the 1984 games in Los Angeles saw ample boycotts resulting from the conflicting tensions and Cold War ideologies.

text.headline: 1988 Presidential Debate - 1
text.text:
25 September 1988

Bush and Dukakis would go head-to-head at Wake Forest University in hopes to sway the American public to select them to be the next President of the United States of America. Public opinion was divided come the conclusion of the debate, which focused on domestic relations and foreign policy.

text.headline: Space Shuttle Mission - 9/29/88
text.text:
29 September 1988

Discovery’s seventh flight, according to NASA, was the 26th NASA Shuttle and the first to return to the STS numbering system; it was known as STS-26. The four-day flight became known by the organization as the “Return to Flight” mission. The moniker emerged as a public-facing campaign to bolster confidence back in space flight following the Space Shuttle Challenger explosion in 1986.
NASA wrote that it also was the first mission to have all crew members wear pressure suits since STS-4, as well as was the first U.S. space mission with an all-veteran crew.

text.headline: 1988 Vice Presidential Debate
text.text:
05 October 1988

Omaha saw a moment that lives in vice presidential history. At the Vice-Presidential Debate, Brokaw’s questioning to Quayle led to his response comparing himself to former president JFK. This prompted his opponent, Bentsen, to say: “Senator, you’re no Jack Kennedy.” While Bentsen didn’t end up winning the vice presidency, his response now permeates the political lexicon. His response is now commonly used to deflate politician’s egos, especially those who thinking too highly of themselves.
This moment was so important that this press pass included a post-it note from Brokaw. The note reads: “This was the Quayle-debate where I asked ? that prompted Bentsen to say to Quayle – “I knew JFK; You’re no JFK…”

text.headline: 1988 Presidential Debate - 2
text.text:
13 October 1988

Bush and Dukakis would head to UCLA to participate in the second presidential debate of the 1988 election. Public opinion of Bush improved, but it may have resulted from Dukakis’s bout with the flu that day. He would spend nearly the entire day in bed and didn’t perform successfully on the debate stage. Brokaw himself would report on the newscast the next night that “The consensus tonight is that Vice President George Bush won last night’s debate and made it all the harder for Governor Michael Dukakis to catch and pass him in the 25 days remaining.”
Dukakis would end up losing the general election to Bush.

text.headline: 1989 Inaugural Ceremonies
text.text:
20 January 1989

The Inauguration of George H.W. Bush, the first and only of his term as President, marked not only a transition from one Republican President to another, but a further cement in the Republican strong hold. Bush, like his predecessor, beat his Democrat opponent in a landslide. Bush’s one-term presidency included seeing the dissolving of the Cold War through, pushing for the reunification of Germany, and ending the first Gulf War.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 2/22/89
text.text:
22 February 1989

In his first international trip as US President, President Bush went on a five-day Pacific tour. All-the-while, back home his nomination for Defense Secretary was facing harsh opposition. According to his Presidential Daily Diaries and the New York Times, Bush believed his trip to be positive, productive, and rewarding. He spoke that the trip “underscored for me what can be achieved through a strong and bipartisan working relationship between the White House and Congress.” Bush also affirmed that this trip meant America would remain a power in the Pacific. To read the NYT article, click here.

text.headline: The Last Surviving Leader of WWII Laid to Rest
text.text:
24 February 1989

While in Japan, President Bush attended the funeral of Emperor Hirohito of Japan., the longest reigning Japanese Emperor The funeral marked the largest event on record, to that date, for attendance of international leaders in world history. The event that would break that record would occur 16 years later following the death of Pope John Paul II.

The New York Times would publish a roll call of the event here.

text.headline: 1989 NATO Summit
text.text:
30 May 1989

Prior to the NATO Summit there was a divide regarding arms policy, particularly relating to the Soviet Union. It would be a proposal from President Bush that would win out and lead to, as the New York Times would report, “a revolutionary conventional arms control agreement” with the Soviet Union. This was considered a moment of mending of the NATO group. An agreement regarding the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear missiles was also reached during this NATO summit. To read the NYT’s story, click here.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 7/9/89
text.text:
09 July 1989

Following his NATO trip, Bush looked to make more history as he joined the G7 in Paris. Ahead of that summit, Bush stopped in both Poland and Hungary. His trip to Warsaw marked a particular moment. There he is remembered proclaiming a “Western vision of the future,” where he looked forward to improving relations in a post-Cold War Europe.

text.headline: Death of Arnaldo Ochoa
text.text: 13 July 1989

text.headline: 1989 G7 Summit
text.text:
14 July 1989

This G7 Summit, which sought to improve economic relations following a contentious decade internationally, was held at the Grande Arche, which the French rushed to complete. It marked the bicentennial of the French Revolution, which some remarked was fitting for the G7 that year. The G7 meeting, given its location, was called the “Summit of the Arch.”

text.headline: Malta Summit
text.text:
02 December 1989

Just a few weeks following the fall of the Berlin Wall, Bush and Gorbachev would meet to officially declare an end to the Cold War. It was the second meeting of the two. The first was held a year previous and included then-president Reagan. News reports called the Malta Summit one of the most important events since World War II.

text.headline: Day in the Life of the White House
text.text: 27 February 1990

text.headline: Paris Summit
text.text:
19 November 1990

The leaders of 34 participating states met to discuss European nations should coordinate following the end of the Cold War. It was decided that Paris Summit meetings would be held every two years. The CSCE was called upon and various offices for it were created. To read more, click here.

text.headline: Geneva Peace Conference
text.text:
09 January 1991

This conference was held to find a solution to Iraq’s occupation of Kuwait and to prevent war between Iraq and the U.S.-supported coalition. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz represented Iraq and Secretary of state James Baker represented the U.S.. The meeting led to the Gulf War.

To read more, click here.

text.headline: Battle of Khafji
text.text:
01 February 1991

This battle, which lasted from January 29th to February 1st 1991, was the first major land battle of the Gulf War. Iraqi forces invaded Saudi Arabia from Southern Kuwait and most were held back by U.S. Marines. Eventually, Iraqi soldiers captured Khafji but it was subsequently recaptured by U.S. and Kuwaiti forces.

text.headline: 1991 G7 Summit
text.text: 15 July 1991

text.headline: 1991 Moscow Summit
text.text:
31 July 1991

This was the final “super power” encounter between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. The meeting resulted in the signing of the START Treaty. Gorbachev and Bush engaged in a nearly five hour talk at a presidential retreat near Moscow.

text.headline: Stanford Finale Weekend
text.text: 28 September 1991

text.headline: 1992 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
13 July 1992

The 1992 Democratic National Convention nominated Bill Clinton for President and Al Gore for Vice President. The convention began with three speeches from Zell Miller, Bill Bradley, and BarZell Millerbala Jordan.

To read more, click here.

text.headline: 1992 Republican National Convention
text.text:
17 August 1992

The 1992 Republican National Convention nominated President George H. W. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle for reelection. It featured the final major address of Ronald Reagan.

text.headline: 1992 Presidential Debate - 1
text.text:
15 October 1992

The second presidential debate of the 1992 General Election featured three candidates: the incumbent President George H.W. Bush, democratic nominee Bill Clinton (then Arkansas’s Governor), and independent Ross Perot. The debate focused on the economy and other domestic issues, but no subject was off limits for the audience of 109 uncommitted voters who served as questioners.

Bush finished the debate in second, but only by one percent over Perot. According to CNN/USA Today, 58% of those polled said Clinton was the clear winner of the debate.

text.headline: 1992 Presidential Debate - 2
text.text:
19 October 1992

The final Presidential Debate of the 1992 General Election again featured all three candidates, with Governor Clinton being viewed as the clear winner. Clinton would go on to win the election.
According to 270 to Win, Clinton received 370 electoral votes and beat Bush in the popular vote by over 5 million. While Perot received 19,742,267 votes in the election, he failed to earn a single electoral vote. This would also be the first election that Nebraska shifted from the traditional winner-take-all approach to electoral votes to the congressional district method.
To see the full breakdown, click here.

text.headline: 1993 Inaugural Ceremonies - 1
text.text:
17 January 1993

Leading up to his Inauguration festivities, Clinton and his VP-Elect Al Gore met with children who won the “Dear Mr. President” essay contest. This event would be followed by a bus tour taking Clinton and Gore to DC and the celebrations of the National Mall.

text.headline: 1993 Inaugural Ceremonies - 2
text.text:
20 January 1993

Bill Clinton was sworn in as the 42nd President of the United States, making him the third youngest president in American history. He also was the first of the Baby Boomer generation to be sworn in as Commander in Chief. Clinton’s inauguration was the 52nd Presidential Inauguration.

text.headline: Superbowl
text.text:
31 January 1993

The Rose Bowl played host to Super Bowl XXVII where the Dallas Cowboys took on the Buffalo Bills. The Cowboys claimed their third title, according to their organization’s site, and Dallas quarterback Troy Aikman was named the MVP of the game. With a total combined score of 69, it was the third highest point total scored in a Super Bowl in the game’s history.

text.headline: Portland Forest Conference
text.text:
02 April 1993

President Clinton’s visit to Portland emphasized a need for environmental protection and awareness. His main purpose being to find more opportunities for jobs and the environment to be connected, leading to a comprehensive national forest policy, according to his Presidential Daily Diaries.
Following this trip, Clinton met with Russian President Boris Yeltsin in Vancouver.

text.headline: Vancouver Summit
text.text:
03 April 1993

Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin met face-to-face to forge a “new democratic partnership,” according to the Washington Post. The two-day summit is generally accepted as being successful with both men leaving feeling satisfied with the outcomes. Clinton and Yeltsin would participate in a joint news conference at the conclusion of the summit where the two would emphasize democratic reform in Russia.
The focal point was a $1.6 billion aid package from the United States.
To read the Washington Post’s coverage, click here.

text.headline: 1993 G7 Summit
text.text:
07 July 1993

The 19th G7 Summit was held in the State Guesthouse in Tokyo. It was the third to be held in Tokyo. While Japan has hosted the G7 Summit since, it has yet to return to Tokyo.

text.headline: JFK Library and Museum Rededication
text.text:
29 October 1993

Rededication of the JFK Library

text.headline: Russia Summit
text.text:
12 January 1994

Clinton would make his first trip to Moscow to reaffirm his agreements with Yeltsin. The meeting also included talks of liquidating military aspects of the Cold War and cooperating to precent nuclear proliferation. The Ukranians were also a part of the talks, which resulted in the elimination of Ukraine’s share of the former Soviet Union’s nuclear arsenal. In a final agreement, Yelstin would attend the next G-7 Summit in Naples, as well as visit the United States.

text.headline: Siege of Sarajevo
text.text:
30 March 1994

The capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina would be central to international news coverage. Sarajevo, besieged by the forces of the Yugolav People’s Army, would be held captive in what is known to be the longest siege in the history of modern warfare. The siege lasted 1,425 during the Bosnian War.

text.headline: Nixon Funeral
text.text:
27 April 1994

Former President Richard M. Nixon passed away at the age of 81. With five presidents in attendance, the nation watched on as Nixon was laid to rest. Clinton delivered the eulogy.
To read about the funeral, click here.

text.headline: D'Day 50th Anniversary
text.text:
06 June 1994

Commemoration of the event

text.headline: Israel-Jordan Peace Treaty
text.text:
26 October 1994

Jordan became the second Arab country, after Egypt, to sign a peace treaty with Israel. The treaty ended a state of wat the two existed under since 1948, thus establishing mutual diplomatic relations. Not only were trade and tourism a part of the treaty, but also settling of disputes over land and water were included. Both countries also agreed to not serve as a military staging ground for strikes by and from a third nation.

text.headline: 1995 Moscow Summit
text.text:
10 May 1995

The two heads of state returned to Moscow to meet to discuss European security as a whole and denouncing the spread of nuclear weaponry. Chechnya was also a point of contention during this meeting. The two could not come to terms on the war within the bounds of the Russian Federation. Clinton and Yeltsin also didn’t agree on Russia stopping their nuclear sales to Iran. This is an issue that still exists in 2021.

text.headline: Benefit Concert
text.text:
10 September 1995

Benefit concert for The Children's Health Fund

text.headline: 1996 New Hampshire Primary
text.text:
20 February 1996

The Democratic primary saw incumbent President Bill Clinton claim a significant victory. He easily won the primary, which would set him on the trajectory to become the party’s nominee for the 1996 General Election.

text.headline: Boxing Night
text.text:
10 May 1996

Mike Tyson returned to the squared circle following a three-year prison term to receive a title match with WBC Heavyweight Champion Frank Bruno. This would be the second time the two would meet. According to The Guardian, the bout should have gone to Lennox Lewis, not Tyson. However, the stories history of the two was something many argue couldn’t be passed up. Tyson would beat Bruno in the third round via technical knockout (TKO).
The bout, which would be Bruno’s last, and the history of the two is the subject of a 2021 documentary.

text.headline: 1996 Olympics
text.text:
19 July 1996

The Summer Olympics were held in Atlanta, Georgia, and the first, according to the IOC, to be held in a different year from the Winter Olympics. With over 10,000 athletes participating in 26 different sports, the games were celebrated. Twenty-four countries made their Olympics debuts, including the 11 former Soviet republics, and three new sports were introduced. Four additional disciplines were added to already included sports, which includes the first introduction of women’s soccer to the Olympics. The United States won 44 golds and 32 silvers, totally 101 medals overall.
However, these Olympics won’t simply be known as the first Summer games to be hosted in a separate year from the Winter Olympic games. A pipe bomb was detonated in Centennial Olympic Park during the events. Two were killed and 111 were injured. Years later, Eric Rudolph admitted to being the bomber and was sentenced to life in prison.

text.headline: 1996 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
26 August 1996

For the first time since the 1968, Chicago was home to the DNC. Chicago has not held a DNC or RNC since. Clinton and Gore would again become their party’s nominees.

text.headline: Princess Diana Funeral
text.text:
06 September 1997

Diana, Princess of Wales, was laid to rest on September 6, 1997. The funeral was estimated to have been watched by 2.5 billion people worldwide, making it one of the biggest televised events in history.
Prior to her untimely death, Diana was marred with controversy. Her very public divorce to Prince Charles and her much talked about interview with Martin Bashir were central to Diana’s demise. In 2021, the BBC found that Bashir used unethical tactics during the interview to get Diana to talk about parts of her life she often kept secret, as well as parts the Royal Family did not want shared.
To read more about the interview, click here.

text.headline: Pope John Paul II Visit to Cuba
text.text:
21 January 1998

Pope John Paul II’s arrival in Cuba was for a specific purpose: hoping the world would “open itself to Cuba.” In his 40 years of leadership, Fidel Castro had not shared a stage with such an important figure.

text.headline: Space Shuttle Mission - 10/29/98
text.text:
29 October 1998

Glenn would become the oldest person to head into space. At 77 years old, Glenn’s voyage with STS-95 on Discovery was highly publicized. The mission also was the first to be publicly broadcast from coast-to-coast. During the trip, Glenn would be used for experiments investigating life sciences, particularly about understanding the human body. Clinton was the only incumbent president since Nixon to witness a space shuttle launch.

text.headline: Pope John Paul II Visit to America
text.text:
26 January 1999

Pope John Paul II spent 31 hours in the United States, in what many describe a whirlwind tour. At 78, the pontiff hosted mass for 104,000 people, persuaded the governor to spare a condemned man, and participated in a youth rally.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/4/99
text.text:
04 May 1999

Members of NATO commenced to address the Kosovo War. The meeting, according to NATO records, is defined as “extraordinary” given the circumstances surrounding the Kosovo War. In a press release, the members of NATO condemned the human rights violations and impediment of democracy. To read the official press release, click here.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 5/5/99
text.text:
05 May 1999

Following his emergency NATO meeting, Bush traveled to Frankfurt to meet with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder. Not only did he participate in governmental business, Bush addressed U.S. military personnel and met with Kosovo War refugees.

text.headline: Millennium Celebration
text.text:
31 December 1999

New Year's Eve celebration -- the new Millennium

text.headline: Pope John Paul II Visit to Palestine
text.text:
22 March 2000

According to the New York Times, Pope John Paul II blended a pilgrimage to the Holy Land with a state-visit to the Palestinian-controlled Bethlehem. It was a day that included moments of silent solitary prayer by the Pope in places where tradition holds that Jesus was born and baptized, contrasted with a gathering in a Palestinian refugee camp where his expressions of sympathy carried strong political echoes.

text.headline: D'Day Museum Grand Opening
text.text:
03 June 2000

This event in New Orleans involved a ribbon-cutting ceremony and a military parade. There was a veterans Tribute led by Tom Brokaw. Finally, there were speeches from people such as Tom Hanks, Leonard Lomell, and Steven Spielberg.

To read more: National D-Day Museum Grand Opening (2000) : Louisiana Digital Media Archive (ladigitalmedia.org)

text.headline: 2000 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
14 August 2000

This convention nominated Al Gore for President and Connecticut Senator Joe Liebeman for Vice President. The convention took place at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. On the final day of the convention, Al Gore accepted the nomination.

text.headline: 2001 Inaugural Ceremonies
text.text:
20 January 2001

George W. Bush was inaugurated as the 43rd U.S. President. Dick Cheney was sworn is as Vice President. After the swearing in, President Bush and First Lady Laura Bush saw former President Bill Clinton off.

text.headline: 2004 New Hampshire Primary
text.text:
27 January 2004

Initially viewed as an untenable candidate for president, John Kerry won the New Hampshire Primary. This victory set the stage for John Kerry to become the Democratic Nominee for President.

text.headline: WWII Memorial Dedication Ceremony
text.text:
29 May 2004

More than 150,000 people gathered for the ceremony of this dedication nearly 59 years after the end of WWII. Notable speakers included Tom Brokaw, Tom Hanks, Senator Bob Dole, and Frederick Smith. The formal dedication included a presentation of state flags and an invocation by Archbishop Philip M. Hannan.

text.headline: 2004 Democratic National Convention
text.text:
26 July 2004

The 2004 Democratic National Convention took place at the FleetCenter in Boston. It nominated Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts for President and Senator John Edwards of North Carolina for vice president. The convention included a keynote speech by Barack Obama.

text.headline: 2004 Olympics
text.text:
13 August 2004

The 2004 Summer Olympics took place in Athens, Greece from August 13th to 29th.There were 10,625 athletes competing in 301 medal events in 28 different sports.

text.headline: 2004 Presidential Debate
text.text:
30 September 2004

This 90-minute debate between George W. Bush and John F. Kerry took place at the University of Miami. It was moderated by Jim Lehrer of PBS.

text.headline: NATO Visit
text.text:
04 October 2005

Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, Nato Secretary General, arrived in Afghanistan with a North Atlantic Council Delegation. This delegation consisted of representatives from 26 nations in NATO. Meetings ensued which involved discussion on how to assist the future stability of a Democratic Republic in Afghanistan.

text.headline: 2006 Olympics
text.text:
10 February 2006

The 2006 Winter Olympics took place in Turin, Piedmont, Italy from February 10th to 26th.. 2,629 athletes competed in 84 separate events. Germany achieved first place, the U.S. got second, and Austria got third.

text.headline: 9/11 Five Years Later
text.text:
11 September 2006

Commemoration of the fifth anniversay of September 11.

text.headline: Ford Funeral
text.text:
02 January 2007

The funeral of Former President Gerald Ford took place on January 2nd in Grand Rapids, Michigan. The casket was flown to Grand Rapids on Air Force One. A public service took place at the Grace Episcopal Church and a private service took place at the Gerald R. Ford Presidential Museum.

text.headline: Masters
text.text:
10 April 2008

The 72nd Masters Tournament at Augusta National Golf Club ended with Trevor Immelman won his first major title, three strokes ahead of runner-up and four-time champion Tiger Woods.

text.headline: 2008 Republican National Convention
text.text:
01 September 2008

The United States 2008 Republican National Convention took place at the Xcel Energy Center in Saint Paul, Minnesota. The attending delegates at the convention nominated Senator John McCain from Arizona for president and Governor Sarah Palin of Alaska for vice president. McCain would ultimately lose the election to the young senator from Illinois, Barack Obama.

text.headline: 2009 Inaugural Ceremonies
text.text:
20 January 2009

President Barack Obama's first inauguration marked the swearing in of the 22th President of the United States of America--the 56th inauguration in American history. Obama's event is considered to be one of the most-observed events in global history. In addition to a large audience of celebrities, it is also the first time the entire length of the National Mall was opened as the public viewing area for the swearing-in ceremony.

text.headline: Presidential Trip - 6/5/09
text.text:
05 June 2009

President Barack Obama and German Chancellor Angela Merkel met together to discuss transatlantic diplomacy, while also visiting former Nazi concentration camp Buchenwald, an event emphasizing WW2 rememberance.

text.headline: 20th Anniversary of the Fall of the Berlin Wall
text.text:
09 November 2009

Fall of the wall, 20 years later

text.headline: 2010 Olympics
text.text:
12 February 2010

Vancouver played host to the 2010 Winter Olympics, with approximately 2,600 athletes from 82 nations participating in 86 events in 15 disciplines. The 2010 Winter Olympics were the third Olympics hosted by Canada and the first by the province of British Columbia.

text.headline: 2016 Olympics
text.text:
05 August 2016

The United States topped the medal counts in the 2016 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XXXI Olympiad (Portuguese: Jogos da XXXI Olimpíada), held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The games were held in South America for the first time in Olympic history, as well as were the first to be held in a Portuguese-speaking nation. The games also were the first to be held in the Souther Hemisphere; the last was Australia in 2000.

text.headline: 2016 Presidential Debate
text.text:
19 October 2016

The third and final debate of the 2016 election took place at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. The debate, moderated by Fox's Chris Wallace, is where Trump would call Clinton a "Nasty Woman." The name would become an anthem for women's marches nationwide. The debate is also the first to have a Fox News host moderate. While Clinton is seen as the better performer, Trump's use of "bad hombres" and "nasty woman" gave him the viral success he wanted.

text.headline: Iowa v. Michigan
text.text:
12 November 2016

Iowa football v. Michigan

text.headline: 2017 Inaugural Ceremonies
text.text:
20 January 2017

The innauguration of the 45th President of the United States of America: Donald J. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence.
